clean_story:
Power over others. The hidden price of holding it.


The phrase "the cost of control" refers to what you lose when you force things—or people—to obey you.


Control feels like a lever: pull it, and everything moves as you want.
But levers also wear out.
The more you use them, the looser they get.
A manager who micromanages every task gains short-term precision but loses creativity.
A parent who dictates every choice raises obedient children, not independent thinkers.
History shows the pattern:
The Soviet Union’s five-year plans boosted industry but stifled innovation, leaving it decades behind in technology.
Schools that enforce silence get quiet classrooms—but students who forget how to ask questions.
Even in nature, control backfires.
Farmers who drown fields in pesticides kill pests and the soil’s ability to regenerate.
The cost isn’t just what you spend to maintain control.
It’s what never gets the chance to grow.


Trust.
Adaptation.
The things you didn’t know you needed.
